title: Indian lodging platform Oyo raises US$1.5 billion
text:
The room-booking platform is the country’s second most valuable startup, with a network of 10,000 smaller hotel properties. SoftBank, Lightspeed Ventures and Sequoia Capital’s Indian fund will invest a combined US$800 million in the Series F round. Oyo founder Ritesh Agarwal’s firm is buying shares worth US$700 million, including some of Lightspeed and Sequoia’s holdings. The new funding will in part support Oyo’s US$300-million push into the U.S. (Mint, Bloomberg)

Talking point: Oyo raised this round amid growing dissatisfaction among the hotels whose rooms it lists. Operators say the platform charges hidden commissions on top of its 20 to 25 per cent franchise levy, adding up to half or more of their revenue on bookings. Hundreds claim to have abandoned the platform, while two operators filed police complaints against it in September; a judge has stayed one. The unrest is significant for Agarwal and SoftBank, which owns about 45 per cent of the firm. Unlike Airbnb, Oyo mostly lists rooms in existing hotels, not private residences, and it invests in the renovation of the properties in addition to providing standardized training and fixtures. That means its capital costs are higher than other short-term rental platforms. It’s a standard model for the “sharing” economy in India—Uber competitor Ola Cabs’ rides in big cities are primarily fleet taxis—but one that makes it harder to replace service providers if they quit.
